They had a copyright though, it's just expired. But moreover, I was referring to the term itself. Something can be copyrighted, public domain, or royalty free. There's no "copyright free" distinction for media.

There are no benefits to joining an MCN in 2017, least of all for a channel of your size.
The usage of that song, as you describe it, would NOT qualify for fair use. Unless you're doing reviews/news-reporting, it's best to steer clear of all third-party material you don't own the rights / licence to.

Wasn't being sassy so much as incredulous. Like, for 'practice editing' - anything will work. Was surprised by his question, more than anything.

Literally anywhere? If it's just practice, re-cut your favorite movie. Download YouTube footage and make a montage, write a script and find stock footage to match, visit archive.org and repurpose public domain clips, make a music video for your favorite song. Or just shoot some stuff yourself.
Like, literally anywhere.

... but, sometimes the "manual" claims are initiated by automatic protocols / rules. It's dumb and confusing, I know :)

You know how I know you're an idiot?
*(first time I've visited this sub in months, btw)*

Cpm refers to the money made per 1k views
It actually refers to the COST to the advertiser for 1,000 views. 45% of which goes to YouTube. Technically, the term we should all be using is "RPM", but it seems unlikely that'll catch on. The terms are NOT interchangable, and yet - to the lay-person, they basically are.

As always - [please see my video on Content ID](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slgldWAsB0M). These claims aren't "wrongful" - the rejected disputes are :-)
You should appeal them.
Easiest way is to draft a simple contract between you, and just pay him monthly. If you cross $600 on the year, draft a 1099 for him.
The fact that it's YouTube-related, and more than ~3 months old disqualifies it outright. Shit changes in this space month-to-month. I wouldn't trust any "guides" written prior to this year.
As with his previous posts, Sugi's 'advice' about MCNs is misleading and inadvisable - ignore this article.

From the [eBay listing](http://www.ebay.com/itm/Rare-Back-To-Future-3-Screen-Used-Movie-Prop-Baby-Crib-Michael-J-Fox-With-Coa-/371832701922),
*This is an original movie prop for back to future 3 . This was a gift from a prop master to a friend of mine a long time ago . This was used in a scene where they were in the west and there was a bag in a crib in a barn . It resembles the crib as well in previous movie where Marty travels to 1955 and meets his uncle In a crib. It comes with authenticity from the gallery for the estate the collection came from . Very nice original movie prop. I have many other movie prop screen used costume items . Please see my store .*
Anyone know which scene / shot he's referring to? I just checked part III, and the crib William McFly is towards the beginning of the movie is a traditional wooden rocker, not a prison-like cage like this. No idea what "barn" he's referring to either. Doc's workshop? No cribs in there, either.

Yes and yes. I wouldn't have suggested you negotiate otherwise. Just a simple, "Thank you for your interest. Would you be willing to pay $650?"
The agreement was for a two year, exclusive arrangement, correct? $500 is fair, but never hurts to ask for more. Worst that happens is they say "no", and you just agree to the original price.
Future Bond girl!
Yah, I have PLENTY of experience. My stuff has been seen in a few TV shows, on airplanes, Roku boxes, news reports, restaurants... what would you like to know?

Are they taking over monetization claim on the upload? How much would that video make you over two years? Ask for at least 1.25x that amount.
Doubtful it's fake - which is why you should definitely counter and begin a negotiation.
You still earn money from age-restricted videos via RED, too.

WRITING.TITLE: /r/BuildAPC, what's the oldest functioning part of your current rig?
WRITING.TEXT: Just wanted to start an informal survey... thought it'd lead to some fun discussions!

To be fair, the viewer-comments are a very small portion of the show now, as I'm only including them for one-review per episode.
I used to read them out-loud - but it was much easier from a production standpoint to add them in post. Plus, it gives me an opportunity to share a small section of the film's music. But yeh, it's a tricky balance. Appreciate the feedback :)

Cool, thanks :)
And the "Movie Night"? - Still feels 'too scripted', or is there any improvement there?
Seen this film at least 5 times, and never put this together - but that's a pretty legitimate plot hole, IMO.
Thanks again for your insight, Groodles! But I was talking to RadicalTzar.
Thanks for the response. Not sure what to do with it, but thanks. Curious though, how recently did you watch Movie Night? Sounds like years ago...?
I may have transposed the names - but there were multiple endings.
Looking him outside of the cage thing with no way to get to Relashaan was perverse fun.
I know the feeling. I film and add media far quicker than I can produce or cosume out.
https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/1722171?hl=en
Will do, thank you again!

Yeh, it's a catch-22 I've struggled with. Watch my new "Anaconda" reviews from the other night, and leave a comment and let me know if you think it's improved any. I recently got a teleprompter, and within the last year, have been trying to phase in more conversational-words into my reviews so they don't seem as "prepared".
But that's the only one I do that is actually scripted - my other 15+ shows are all improvised :)

I have! It sounds like you're already familiar with my newest project, "Tech Check" - but response to that was really positive, so I'm looking forward to producing more of those. I've never quite had the cult-of-personality for straight-entertainment, but informational/educational programming about technology or movie analysis seems to be a better fit. Just gotta build (another) audience for it.
As for FilmRiot, I have to admit I'm not familiar with their channel - but I love "Every Frame A Painting" - Tony's insight makes me look like a high school drop out, and not someone with a media-degree and a decade of film-reviewing experience! I hope to try my first long-form, more analytical reviews later this year in a sub-series about "film theory", and shit like that. Some might just be goofy (like how "Face/Off" is the most insane movie ever made) - whereas others might be a serious look at how 9/11 killed the rom-com.
Again, no idea if there's an audience for that - but I'm fascinated and motivated to try, so I think I will. In the meantime, keep an eye out for an awesome new super-cut I'll be releasing this week or the next! (Also, I still do those live-editing videos every few months, search YouTube for "Jon Edits").

1) Google Alerts
2) I Reddit a lot. Guessing I'd be mentioned in a thread about old YouTubers is a pretty safe bet.
3) Fans/friends often @reply me directly to notify me. (Happened 3x for this thread)
4) Viewership sees a small bump, not too hard to trace back.
Thank you for watching :)

Glad you respect our decision! Many on Reddit don't seem to share that viewpoint ;-)
Thanks for keeping with me, too!
Eh, sorry - but no. That's a very liberal interpretation of that word. "Post-fame", maybe - but if a channel is actively uploading, they are very much not "dead".

I don't know how to PM from mobile, haha -but my business email is public anyway,
Jon@Jogwheel.com
Haha, happy to have helped :-)
The stats and import feature + knowing you're supporting a small dev team make it worth it, IMO.

While that moment was obviously unscripted and real - our personalities are, ironically, usually the reverse. I'm the one who wanted to push the limits, whereas Jory tended to be more cautious. Riley however was pretty much down for whatever, haha.
Yeah you did! I still recognize your screen name :-)
Dude, that's awesome to hear - good for you. NYC is a tough market. As for editing work, I could certainly use help (my backlog is immense), but my wallet is empty :-(

You have no idea how wonderful this is to hear :-)
How's your filmmaking going now? Still doing anything with cameras? You must be about 23 now?

Precisely. My "Roller Coaster Commotion" show always did very well (critically, views, revenue) - But actually filming a new season requires flying two or more people across the country, renting hotel rooms, and paying for safety insurance so theme parks will allow us to film. Sure, the show should eventually make back that $3,000+ budget, but it'd take years, and not even a guarantee than.
Thanks to you as well. Have a lovely weekend.

Hmm, the first one is something I totally would have done. I was angry and defensive then. But earlier this year? Sorry man, I'm usually better than that. Could have caught me on a bad day, honestly. Thanks for watching all those years ago though! The fact that you cared enough to comment means a lot, even if I replied like an asshole.
Same to you, /uPusher_ :-)
You should be my psychiatrist. Lol.
You remembered the "fucking" part! I edited that out of the title sequence clip, and often forget my original quote!
